Introduction

Nipple discharge is a common clinical presentation and can be physiologic (eg, galactorrhea) or pathologic (ie, due to an abnormal process within the breast).  Although most cases are benign, a thorough evaluation is required to establish the etiology and rule out malignancy.

Pathogenesis



The breast is composed of glandular tissue (lobules and ducts) surrounded by adipose and connective tissue (

figure 1
).  Breast milk is made in the lobules and then drained by mammary ducts, which converge into the lactiferous sinuses beneath the nipple.  The lobules and ducts are lined with epithelial cells that respond to hormonal and local stimuli.  Nonlactation discharge from the nipple also arises from this glandular tissue and may involve single or multiple ducts.  Nipple discharge that is not related to lactation is broadly categorized as physiologic (ie, benign) or pathologic (ie, concerning for malignancy).

Physiologic nipple discharge



Physiologic nipple discharge (also known as galactorrhea) is a bilateral, multiductal, nonbloody discharge with a normal breast examination.  It is not related to lactation and is most often due to a systemic cause (rather than the breast itself).  Causes of physiologic discharge include:



  • Nipple stimulation.
  • Hyperprolactinemia (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: video 1
    ):  Elevated levels of prolactin stimulate breast glandular tissue, producing nipple discharge.  High prolactin levels can occur due to chest wall injury (eg, burns, herpes zoster), pituitary or hypothalamic disease (infiltrative disorders, prolactinoma), medications (eg, antipsychotics), hypothyroidism, or renal disease (due to reduced clearance of prolactin).

Pathologic nipple discharge



Pathologic nipple discharge is unilateral, often uniductal, and varies in color (bloody is most concerning for malignancy).  It is due to an abnormal process within the breast, which may be benign or malignant.



Lactation (breast milk secretion) is covered in detail in a separate review article.

Clinical presentation and assessment



Nipple discharge may be spontaneous or provoked (ie, elicited with breast manipulation).  Other features categorize the discharge as physiologic or pathologic, which guides the diagnostic work-up.



  • Physiologic discharge is bilateral, multiductal, and nonbloody (most often milky, clear, or gray- colored).
  • Pathologic discharge is unilateral, uniductal, and bloody or serosanguineous.


In addition, a thorough review of systems, medication review, and clinical breast examination are needed.  Key associated symptoms and history-related findings that help narrow the diagnosis include:



  • Breast mass, pain, or changes in appearance to the breast (suggestive of mastitis, Paget disease of the breast, inflammatory breast cancer).
  • Menstrual abnormalities (suggestive of pregnancy or hyperprolactinemia (
    figure 2
    )).
  • Male infertility or erectile dysfunction (suggestive of hyperprolactinemia).
  • Headaches or visual field changes (suggestive of pituitary masses).


  • Medications:  Dopamine antagonists (eg, antipsychotics, metoclopramide) can cause hyperprolactinemia while hormonal therapies (eg, estrogen, progesterone) can stimulate physiologic nipple discharge.
  • Recent pregnancy or lactation history.
  • Family history of malignancy.


The clinical breast examination begins with noted skin changes, nipple retraction, ulceration, and asymmetry.  Palpation of the breast evaluates masses, tenderness, induration of the breast, and axillary or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy.  An attempt to express the discharge by gently squeezing around the nipple, noting the color and consistency of any elicited discharge, is also performed.

Diagnostic evaluation



The approach to further evaluation of nipple discharge depends on whether the clinical assessment indicates that it is physiologic or pathologic:

Physiologic nipple discharge



Diagnostic work-up of physiologic nipple discharge (eg, both nipples involved, milky or clear discharge, no abnormalities on breast examination) begins with laboratory testing (because it is most likely due to a systemic cause) and includes:



  • Pregnancy test
  • TSH level
  • Prolactin level
  • Renal function testing


Additional evaluation may be indicated based on the suspected cause (eg, MRI for suspected prolactinoma).  Breast imaging is not routinely performed for physiologic discharge, but patients age â‰¥40 should be up to date with screening mammography.

Pathologic nipple discharge



Pathologic nipple discharge (eg, unilateral, bloody, breast mass) does not require laboratory testing because it is more likely caused by intrinsic breast pathology rather than systemic causes.  Therefore, evaluation centers around age-based breast imaging (

figure 3
).



  • Age <30:  Breast ultrasonography is first-line imaging for this age group because younger women have greater breast density, which limits mammography sensitivity.
  • Age â‰¥30:  Mammography is first-line imaging for this age group and identifies findings suspicious for malignancy (eg, calcifications, asymmetry, architectural distortion). Ultrasonography is often performed in addition to mammography because it is useful for evaluation of mammary ducts, differentiating between cystic and solid lesions, and identifying lesions that may be missed on mammography (eg, lesions that are small, intraductal, or lack calcifications).
  • Age â‰¥40:  Mammography and ultrasonography are both used due to the increased likelihood of malignancy with increasing age.


Breast MRI is used when mammography and ultrasonography findings are negative in patients with pathologic nipple discharge.



Galactography and ductoscopy are less commonly used imaging modalities because they are technically challenging; therefore, they are used only when other imaging techniques fail to identify a cause.



Abnormalities detected on imaging are further evaluated by core needle biopsy to establish a histologic diagnosis (

figure 4
).  Cytology of nipple discharge is not routinely performed because it has poor sensitivity and specificity and cannot localize breast lesions.

Management

Physiologic nipple discharge



Patients with normal endocrine testing require no additional management other than routine breast screening.  Premenopausal women can have transient, idiopathic galactorrhea that is benign and typically self-resolves.  Education is often provided about avoiding nipple stimulation (eg, excessive self-examination, sexual stimulation).



Hyperprolactinemia is addressed in detail in a separate article.

Pathologic nipple discharge



Management of pathologic nipple discharge depends on the underlying cause:



  • Intraductal papilloma (
    figure 5
    ):  This is a benign papillary projection lined by epithelial and myoepithelial cells. It is the most common cause of pathologic nipple discharge.  Management is with surgical excision because these papillomas may harbor areas of atypia or ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS).  If discharge persists following excision, the entire duct may be excised.
  • Malignancy (eg, invasive ductal carcinoma, inflammatory breast cancer):  Treatment may involve surgery (eg, lumpectomy or mastectomy), chemotherapy, radiation, or hormonal therapy, depending on tumor characteristics.
  • Mastitis or abscess:  Periductal mastitis can occur outside of lactation, particularly in women who smoke.  Superimposed bacterial infections can lead to purulent breast discharge or abscess formation.  Treatment involves antibiotics, and abscesses may require aspiration or incision and drainage.
  • Mammary duct ectasia:  Fibrosis and inflammation can lead to subareolar duct distension that can cause a palpable mass with sticky, green-brown discharge.  It is managed with observation or duct excision for symptom relief
  • No identifiable lesion:  When imaging or biopsy fails to identify the cause of nipple discharge, excision of the involved duct is the preferred management to resolve symptoms and rule out underlying malignancy.

Summary



Nipple discharge is classified as physiologic or pathologic.  Physiologic discharge is often bilateral, multiductal, nonspontaneous, and systemic or endocrine in origin.  In contrast, pathologic discharge is typically unilateral, spontaneous, and bloody or serous.  The evaluation for physiologic discharge involves laboratory testing to rule out pregnancy and hormonal conditions.  Patients with pathologic nipple discharge undergo age-based diagnostic breast imaging with biopsy depending on imaging results.
